slides.title: Events That Get Attendance

content.headline: How to Create Events People Actually Attend
content.subhead: The difference between an event that flops and one that fills up

expectations.outcome: A compelling event that drives attendance

slides.narration: There's a huge difference between posting an event and posting an event people actually attend. In the next ten minutes, I'm going to show you exactly what makes the difference. By the end, you'll know how to create events that fill up, not flop.

slides.title: The Anatomy of a Great Event

content.headline: What Makes Events Work
content.insight: Most events fail because they're vague. Specificity wins.

slides.narration: Great events have five things. A compelling title—this alone can triple your clicks. Clear value—people need to know why they should care. Specific details—date, time, location, what to expect. A great image—doubles your engagement. And an easy action—one click to RSVP or save. Most events fail because they're too vague. Specificity wins.

slides.title: Step 1: Write a Great Title

content.headline: Step 1: Write a Title That Gets Clicks
good_examples: 50% Off Everything: Summer Blowout at Martinez Boutique
Free DIY Home Repair Workshop (Learn to Fix Anything)
Grand Opening Celebration: Free Samples & Live Music
content.tip: Ask yourself: Would I click on this?

slides.narration: Step one: write a title that gets clicks. Use this formula: benefit or hook, plus what it is, plus your business name. Bad titles are vague: 'Sale Event,' 'Workshop,' 'Grand Opening.' Good titles are specific: 'Fifty Percent Off Everything: Summer Blowout at Martinez Boutique.' 'Free DIY Home Repair Workshop—Learn to Fix Anything.' Ask yourself: would I click on this? If not, rewrite it.

slides.title: Step 2: Make the Value Clear

content.headline: Step 2: Answer 'Why Should I Care?'
questions_to_answer: What's in it for me specifically?

value_examples.value: Leave with 3 skills you can use immediately
Save $50-200 on items you're already buying
Free food, live music, 20% off your first visit

content.tip: Lead with the benefit, not the logistics.

slides.narration: Step two: make the value clear. Answer the question: why should I care? What will I get, learn, or experience? Is it worth my time? What's in it for me? For a workshop: 'Leave with three skills you can use immediately.' For a sale: 'Save fifty to two hundred dollars on items you're already buying.' Lead with the benefit, not the logistics. People need to want it before they need the details.

slides.title: Step 3: Include All the Details

content.headline: Step 3: Remove Every Barrier
content.checklist: If someone has to ask a question before attending, you forgot something.

slides.narration: Step three: include all the details. Every question someone might have, answer it. Date and time—include the day of week and timezone. Location—full address plus parking notes. Cost—say if it's free. What to bring or expect—reduce the anxiety about showing up. And if there's limited capacity, say so—it creates urgency. Here's your test: if someone would have to ask a question before attending, you forgot something.

slides.title: Step 4: Choose a Great Image

content.headline: Step 4: Use an Image That Pops
image_tips: Show the experience—people enjoying, learning, participating
Bright, well-lit photos outperform dark ones
Faces get more engagement than objects
Don't use stock photos if you have real ones
content.no_image: No photo? Use an eye-catching graphic or your best storefront shot.

slides.narration: Step four: use an image that pops. Show the experience—people enjoying themselves, learning something, participating. Bright, well-lit photos outperform dark ones. Faces get more engagement than objects. Horizontal orientation displays best across platforms. And if you have real photos from past events, use those instead of stock photos. Minimum 1200 by 630 pixels for best display.

slides.title: Step 5: Add Urgency & Action

content.headline: Step 5: Make Taking Action Easy
urgency_techniques: Early bird: 'First 10 registrations get a bonus'
Deadline: 'RSVP by Friday for free parking'
Scarcity: 'Last year sold out in 3 days'
content.tip: Every extra step loses 50% of attendees. Make it frictionless.

slides.narration: Step five: add urgency and make action easy. Urgency techniques: 'Only 20 spots available.' 'First ten registrations get a bonus.' 'RSVP by Friday.' 'Last year sold out.' Then make the action frictionless. One-click RSVP, no account required. Add to calendar button. Share button. Remember: every extra step you add loses fifty percent of attendees. Friction kills attendance.
